hadiths.english_translation: Narrated by al-Rabi': What does one of you do with speech after nine: Glorified be Allah, Praise be to Allah, there is no god but Allah, Allah is the Greatest, Enjoining good, Forbidding evil, Recitation of the Qur'an, Asking Allah for good, and Seeking refuge in Him from evil.

narrators.name: al-Rabi'
narrators.alternative_names: al-Rabi' ibn Khuthaym, Abu Yazid al-Bahili

chainIssues: Hadith is maqta' (completely cut off) - no chain of transmission provided from al-Rabi' to the Prophet ﷺ
No prior narrators or collectors mentioned
This is a disconnected statement without proper isnad

potential_issues.issue: Complete disconnection from isnad
potential_issues.impact: This hadith lacks any chain of transmission. It appears to be a statement from al-Rabi' ibn Khuthaym without any narrators connecting it to him or further up the chain. This is a fundamental weakness in the hadith.

hadiths.IISGrade: Disconnections But All Narrators Are Ok
Topics: Nine types of beneficial speech and remembrance
Glorification of Allah
Praise of Allah
Testimony of faith
Enjoining good and forbidding evil
Recitation of the Qur'an
Supplication and seeking refuge in Allah

hadiths.english_translation: Narrated by Hubairah ibn Hazimah: When Husayn was killed, I came to al-Rabi' ibn Khuthaym and informed him, then he recited this verse: 'O Allah, Creator of the heavens and the earth, Knower of the unseen and the seen, You judge between Your servants regarding that in which they differ.' (Surah Az-Zumar, verse 46)

narrators.name: Muhammad ibn Abdullah al-Asadi
narrators.full_name: Muhammad ibn Abdullah ibn Muhammad al-Asadi
reliabilityIssues: Limited sources attest to his reliability

chainIssues: Mixed transmission terms: حَدَّثَنَا and عَنْ create some ambiguity
Muhammad ibn Abdullah al-Asadi is not widely known, raising questions about his reliability
Nuseir ibn Dhu'looq's narration using 'an is potentially ambiguous

potential_issues.issue: Muhammad ibn Abdullah al-Asadi is relatively obscure
potential_issues.impact: This narrator is not well-documented in hadith literature, which raises some concerns about his reliability level. He is rated as Saduq but not extensively verified.

potential_issues.issue: Use of 'an (عَنْ) by Nuseir ibn Dhu'looq
potential_issues.impact: The transmission through 'an creates slight ambiguity in the connection, though this does not severely impact the hadith given the overall reliability of other narrators in the chain.

potential_issues.issue: Hadith is mawquf (stopped at companion level)
potential_issues.impact: This hadith does not reach the Prophet ﷺ; it stops at the account of Hubairah ibn Hazimah about al-Rabi' ibn Khuthaym's reaction to the news of Husayn's death.

Topics: Reaction to the death of Husayn ibn Ali
Recitation of Qur'anic verse in response to calamity
Incident of al-Rabi' ibn Khuthaym hearing about Husayn's death

hadiths.english_translation: Narrated by Abu Ya'la: There were thirty men in Banu Thawr, no man among them inferior to Rabi' ibn Khuthaym.

narrators.name: Qabisah ibn Uqbah
narrators.full_name: Qabisah ibn Uqbah ibn Nafi al-Kufi
narrators.alternative_names: Qabisah ibn Uqbah, Abu Aziz al-Kufi

chainIssues: Use of 'an (عَنْ) by al-A'laa ibn al-Musayyab, which is ambiguous regarding direct transmission
All narrators otherwise appear reliable

potential_issues.issue: Use of 'an by al-A'laa ibn al-Musayyab
potential_issues.impact: While al-A'laa is generally reliable, the use of 'an introduces slight ambiguity. However, al-A'laa is not known as a mudallis, so this does not significantly compromise the chain.

potential_issues.issue: Hadith is mawquf (stopped at companion level)
potential_issues.impact: This is a statement from Abu Ya'la about Rabi' ibn Khuthaym and the people of Banu Thawr, not a hadith from the Prophet ﷺ.

hadiths.english_translation: Narrated by Shubrumah: I did not see in Kufa a living elder, jurist, and worshipper more abundant from Banu Thawr.

hadiths.english_translation: Narrated by the father of Abu Bakr al-Zubaidi: I have not seen a people sitting more frequently in the mosques than the Thawrites and the 'Uraynites.

narrators.name: Qabisah ibn Uqbah
narrators.full_name: Qabisah ibn Uqbah ibn Nafi al-Kufi

chainIssues: Abu Bakr al-Zubaidi uses 'an which creates minor ambiguity in transmission
Father of Abu Bakr is unnamed and relies on the identification through Abu Bakr

potential_issues.issue: Abu Bakr al-Zubaidi uses indirect transmission term 'an
potential_issues.impact: While Abu Bakr al-Zubaidi is graded as Thiqah, the use of 'an creates slight ambiguity about the directness of transmission from his father, though this is mitigated by his high reliability grade.

potential_issues.issue: Father of Abu Bakr al-Zubaidi is unnamed
potential_issues.impact: The hadith refers to the father only through Abu Bakr's identification. While this is a normal practice, it introduces minor ambiguity in the full identification of this narrator.

potential_issues.issue: Hadith is mawquf (stopped at companion level)
potential_issues.impact: This hadith does not reach the Prophet ﷺ but is a statement from the father of Abu Bakr al-Zubaidi about the devotion of the Thawrites and 'Uraynites.

Description of specific tribes' commitment to congregational worship

hadiths.english_translation: Narrated by Yusuf ibn al-Hajjaj al-Anmati: I heard al-Rabi' ibn Khuthaym saying: 'That I overturn with my hand the fat of a pig is more beloved to me than that I overturn the dice of Nard-Shir.'

narrators.name: Abdullah ibn Ja'far
narrators.full_name: Abdullah ibn Ja'far ibn Muhammad al-Madini

chainIssues: Use of 'an by Yusuf ibn al-Hajjaj al-Anmati is offset by the explicit hearing term سَمِعْتُ used by Yusuf when stating 'I heard al-Rabi'
All narrators in the chain are graded as Thiqah

potential_issues.issue: Use of 'an by Yusuf ibn al-Hajjaj
potential_issues.impact: While Yusuf ibn al-Hajjaj uses 'an, this is mitigated by the fact that he explicitly states 'سَمِعْتُ' (I heard) when describing his direct hearing from al-Rabi'. This demonstrates direct transmission from al-Rabi'.

Topics: Statement of al-Rabi' ibn Khuthaym forbidding gambling
Comparison of forbidden gambling with impure substances
Rejection of games of chance by the pious

hadiths.english_translation: Narrated by al-Sha'bi: We entered upon Rabi' ibn Khuthaym to visit him. We said to him: 'Pray to Allah for us.' He said: 'O Allah, to You belongs all praise, in Your hand is all good, to You returns all affairs, You are the God of all creation, we ask You for all good and seek refuge in You from all evil.'

chainIssues: All narrators are graded as Thiqah
Direct transmission terms used throughout (أَخْبَرَنَا)

potential_issues.issue: Hadith is mawquf (stopped at companion level)

Topics: Supplication taught by al-Rabi' ibn Khuthaym
Form of prayer praising Allah and His attributes
Incident of visiting a sick believer

hadiths.english_translation: Narrated by an unnamed man from Banu Taym Allah from his father: I accompanied Rabi' ibn Khuthaym for two years, and he did not ask me about anything concerning worldly matters, except that once he said to me: 'Is your mother alive? How many mosques do you have?'

narrators.name: Qabisah ibn Uqbah
narrators.full_name: Qabisah ibn Uqbah ibn Nafi al-Kufi

potential_issues.issue: Unknown narrator in the chain
potential_issues.impact: The chain contains an unnamed man from Banu Taym Allah, making him Majhul al-'Ayn (individual of unknown identity). This is a critical weakness in hadith transmission, as we cannot verify the reliability of an unnamed narrator.

potential_issues.issue: Father of unknown narrator is also unnamed
potential_issues.impact: The chain continues through the father of this unknown man, who is similarly unnamed and unknown. This compounds the reliability issue in the chain.

potential_issues.issue: Hadith is mawquf (stopped at companion level)

Incident showing al-Rabi's otherworldly focus

hadiths.english_translation: Narrated by al-Rabi' ibn Khuthaym: What I love most is the supplication of the slave to his Lord, saying: 'O Lord, You have decreed upon Yourself mercy, O Lord, You have decreed upon Yourself mercy.' I have not seen anyone say: 'I have fulfilled what is upon me, so fulfill what is upon You.'

narrators.name: Qabisah ibn Uqbah
narrators.full_name: Qabisah ibn Uqbah ibn Nafi al-Kufi

potential_issues.issue: Multiple indirect transmission terms (عَنْ)
potential_issues.impact: The chain contains two consecutive indirect transmission terms (عَنْ) from Uyaynah ibn Abi Ishaq and Abu Ya'la, which creates ambiguity in the connection. However, both narrators are Thiqah, which mitigates this concern somewhat.

potential_issues.issue: Hadith is mawquf (stopped at companion level)
potential_issues.impact: This hadith does not reach the Prophet ﷺ but is a statement from al-Rabi' ibn Khuthaym about supplication.

Topics: Types of supplication preferred by al-Rabi' ibn Khuthaym
Supplication to Allah acknowledging His mercy and provision
Spiritual teachings of al-Rabi' ibn Khuthaym

hadiths.english_translation: Narrated by Abd Khair: I was a companion of al-Rabi' ibn Khuthaym in a raid, so I mentioned it. He returned with slaves and animals. I waited a few days then came to him, but I did not perceive anything of those slaves or those animals. I asked permission but no one answered me. Then I entered and said: 'Where are your slaves and your animals?' He did not answer me. I repeated, and he said: 'You shall not attain righteousness until you spend from that which you love.' (Surah Al Imran, verse 92)

narrators.name: Sayf ibn Harun
reliabilityIssues: Some scholars criticized his memory in some reports

potential_issues.issue: Sayf ibn Harun is graded Saduq
potential_issues.impact: The presence of Sayf ibn Harun, who is graded as Saduq rather than Thiqah, introduces a reliability concern. While Saduq narrators are generally acceptable, they are not at the highest level of reliability. Some scholars have questioned his accuracy in certain reports.

potential_issues.issue: Use of عَنْ by Abd al-Malik ibn Sal'
potential_issues.impact: The indirect transmission term عَنْ used by Abd al-Malik ibn Sal', while coming from a Thiqah narrator, creates slight ambiguity. This is mitigated by Abd al-Malik's reliability.

potential_issues.issue: Hadith is mawquf (stopped at companion level)

Implementation of the principle of spending from what one loves

hadiths.english_translation: Narrated by al-Hasan: It was said to al-Rabi' ibn Khuthaym when he was afflicted with paralysis: 'If only you would seek treatment.' He said: 'Ad and Thamud have passed, and the Companions of the Well, and generations between them were many. Among them were the describer and the one described, but neither the describer nor the one described remains, except that they have perished.'

narrators.name: al-Hasan
reliabilityIssues: Some scholars questioned his direct hearing from some companions
Generally considered reliable but with minor caveats

hadiths.english_translation: Narrated by al-Rabi' ibn Khuthaym: This is what al-Rabi' ibn Khuthaym attested to for himself and made Allah witness to it. And Allah suffices as witness and recompenser and rewarder of His righteous servants. Verily, I am pleased with Allah as my Lord, with Muhammad as my Prophet, with Islam as my religion, and I am pleased for myself and whoever obeys me that we worship Him among the worshippers, praise Him among the praisers, and give sincere counsel to the community of Muslims.

chainIssues: Use of indirect transmission terms (عَنْ) by Uyaynah and Mundhir

Declaration of accepting Allah as Lord, Muhammad as Prophet, and Islam as religion

hadiths.english_translation: Narrated by Said ibn Masruq: Al-Rabi' ibn Khuthaym made a will. I said: Did you hear it? He said: Our elders and the living informed me. This is what al-Rabi' ibn Khuthaym willed, attested, and made Allah witness to, and Allah suffices as witness and recompenser of His righteous servants. Verily, I am pleased with Allah as my Lord and Islam as my religion and with Muhammad as my Prophet, and I am pleased for myself and whoever follows me from the Muslims that we worship Allah among the worshippers, praise Him among the praisers, and give sincere counsel to the community of Muslims.

hadiths.english_translation: Narrated by Mundhir al-Thawri: Al-Rabi' ibn Khuthaym willed: This is what al-Rabi' ibn Khuthaym willed, attested, and made Allah witness to it, or upon it - Shu'bah doubted. Allah suffices as witness, recompenser, and rewarder of His righteous servants. Verily, I am pleased with Allah as my Lord, with Islam as my religion, with Muhammad ﷺ as my Prophet and Messenger, with the Quran as my guide, and I am pleased for myself and whoever obeyed me from the Muslims that we worship Allah among the worshippers, praise Him among the praisers, and give sincere counsel to the community of Muslims. They said: And al-Rabi' ibn Khuthaym died in Kufa during the governorship of Ubaydullah ibn Ziyad over it.

hadiths.english_translation: Narrated by Muslim Abu Sa'id: I entered with Ibn Mas'ud to Zayd ibn Khulaidah, and he said: 'Verily there will come upon you a day when you would wish what you own for a camel and its saddle.'

narrators.name: Abdullah ibn Mas'ud
narrators.full_name: Abdullah ibn Mas'ud ibn Ghafil al-Hudali

chainIssues: Use of عَنْ by Abu al-Ya'fur creates minor transmission ambiguity
Reference to Ibn Mas'ud as a documented companion in the chain narrators

potential_issues.issue: Use of عَنْ by Abu al-Ya'fur
potential_issues.impact: The indirect transmission term عَنْ used by Abu al-Ya'fur creates slight ambiguity, though both he and the subsequent narrators are Thiqah, which mitigates this concern.

potential_issues.issue: Hadith is mawquf (stopped at companion level)
potential_issues.impact: This hadith does not reach the Prophet ﷺ but is a statement from Zayd ibn Khulaidah as witnessed by Muslim Abu Sa'id accompanying Abdullah ibn Mas'ud.

Topics: Prophecy of future hardship or trials for the Muslim community
Statement about the preference of simple livelihood over worldly possessions
Incident of Ibn Mas'ud visiting Zayd ibn Khulaidah

hadiths.english_translation: Qabisah ibn Burmah al-Asadi was the leader of his people. The stipend was sent to the leader so he would distribute it among those with stipends. I saw the stipend being brought to Qabisah, and he distributed it. (Second version): I saw Qabisah ibn Burmah al-Asadi dyeing with yellow dye (saffron).

chainIssues: Two reports in one entry with different matns
Both are mawquf reports from/through Qabisah

potential_issues.issue: Two hadiths combined into one entry
potential_issues.impact: This entry contains two separate hadith reports: one about distribution of stipends and one about dyeing with saffron. While from the same chain, they represent distinct reports.

potential_issues.issue: Hadith is mawquf (stopped at companion level)
potential_issues.impact: These hadiths do not reach the Prophet ﷺ but are reports from/about Qabisah ibn Burmah al-Asadi.

Topics: Role of Qabisah ibn Burmah as leader in distributing public stipends
Description of Qabisah's personal grooming practices
Administrative responsibility among early Muslims

hadiths.english_translation: Narrated by Abu Wa'il: I met Silah ibn Zufar, and as far as I knew, he was righteous. I said to him: 'Is there among your family any of this illness?' He said: 'No. Rather I fear for them that it will miss them more than I fear for them that it will strike them.' Musa ibn Mas'ud added in his narration: And he was called Abu al-'Ala'. And Silah ibn Zufar died in Kufa during the time of Mus'ab ibn Zubayr, and he was trustworthy and had hadiths.

narrators.name: al-A'mash
reliabilityIssues: Though generally reliable, tadlis must be noted

potential_issues.issue: Muhammad ibn Abdullah al-Asadi is Saduq in first chain
potential_issues.impact: The first chain includes Muhammad ibn Abdullah al-Asadi, who is Saduq rather than Thiqah, which affects the reliability of that particular transmission.

potential_issues.issue: al-A'mash is a known mudallis (Category 2) using عَنْ
potential_issues.impact: al-A'mash is known as a mudallis of Category 2 and uses عَنْ transmission. However, al-A'mash is generally considered reliable even with عَنْ transmission, and his tadlis does not typically affect acceptance of his reports.

potential_issues.issue: Hadith is mawquf (stopped at companion level)
potential_issues.impact: This hadith does not reach the Prophet ﷺ but is an account from Abu Wa'il about Silah ibn Zufar. The text includes a biographical note that Silah was trustworthy (thiqah) and died during Mus'ab ibn Zubayr's time.

Topics: Statement of Silah ibn Zufar about fear for his family's wellbeing
Dialogue between Abu Wa'il and Silah ibn Zufar
Description of Silah's piety and trustworthiness
Historical note about Silah's death during Mus'ab ibn Zubayr's governorship
